XPW v XPX

XPW v XPX
[2025] SGFC 120

Case Number:FC/OAX 1 of 2025
Decision Date:17 November 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Sofia Bakhash (M/s Phoenix Law Corporation) for the Applicant; Ganga d/o Avadiar, Michelle Lynn Fernandez (M/s Advocatus Law LLP) for the Respondent.
Parties: XPW — XPX

Contempt of Court – Civil contempt – No leave was sought to commit care-parent for changing the venue of the child’s religious classes – Care-parent’s decision to change the venue is the subject of a hearing into an application for a personal protection order – Whether appropriate to consider the care-parent’s decision to change the venue of the child’s religious classes in committal proceeding

Contempt of Court – Civil contempt – Care-parent arranges for child to be psychologically assessed and to undergo counselling – Whether care-parent in contempt for failing to seek consent from joint custody parent

Contempt of Court – Civil contempt – Child refuses to attend access – Whether care-parent in contempt of access order

Evidence – “Unusually convincing” standard – Whether applicable to committal proceedings

Family Law – Custody – Care and control – Distinction between custody-related and care-related decisions – “Major healthcare issues” – Whether non-invasive psychological assessment and counselling of the child are “major healthcare issues” which require the consent of the joint custody parent

Family Law – Access – Care-parent’s duty to facilitate access – Requirement of reasonable efforts – Child refuses to proceed with access due to genuine fear of access-parent – Whether care-parent made reasonable efforts to comply with access order

17 November 2025

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       It is a settled principle that a care-parent must make reasonable efforts to comply with an access order – even when the child refuses to see the access-parent. This case concerns the alleged breach of an access order and raises the following questions: What is reasonably expected of the care-parent when the child’s refusal is rooted in fear that the access-parent might commit sexual misconduct against her? Where the care-parent arranges psychological assessment and counselling for the child to address that fear, does this amount to a “major healthcare issue” and thus require the consent of the access-parent (who has joint custody rights over the child)?

2       These questions arise in the present committal application. It is the access-parent’s case that the care-parent has disobeyed access and joint custody orders relating to their daughter. Having considered the evidence and submissions, I found that the access-parent had failed to prove his case beyond a reasonable doubt.

Background

3       The Father and the Mother are divorced. They have two children: a daughter born in October 2014 (“Daughter”) and a son born in September 2011 (“Son”).

4       In 2019, the Daughter alleged on two occasions that the Father had touched her sexually. Police reports were made. She was examined at a hospital and the Child Protective Service was involved. The Police ultimately decided to take no further action regarding the allegations.

5       Following the parties’ divorce, the Syariah Court made the following orders in October 2020 regarding the children: (a) joint custody to both parties (“Custody Order”), (b) care and control to the Mother, and (c) reasonable access to the Father (“2020 Order”).[note: 1]

6       The 2020 Order was varied in November 2024 (“2024 Order”) – the Father was granted care and control of the Son, while the Mother retained care and control of the Daughter. The Father’s access to the Daughter was amended to unsupervised access every other weekend (“Access Order”).[note: 2]

The parties’ case

7       The Father alleges that the Mother had breached the Custody Order by (a) arranging psychological assessment and counselling for the Daughter at KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital (“KKH”) in 2024 and (b) changing the venue of the child’s religious classes without his consent. He further alleges that she had breached the Access Order by denying him access to the daughter on five occasions between December 2024 and February 2025 (“Relevant Access Period”).

8       The Mother accepts that she had arranged the KKH consultations and changed the Daughter’s religious classes without the Father’s consent. She contends, however, that she was entitled to make these decisions in her capacity as the care-parent and that her actions did not infringe the Father’s joint custody rights over the child.[note: 3] She further accepts that the Daughter did not attend access during the Relevant Access Period. She explains that this was because the child was fearful of the Father and did not wish to see him.[note: 4]

Applicable principles – Committal

9       The principles governing committal proceedings are well established: Mok Kah Hong v Zheng Zhuan Yao [2016] 3 SLR 1 (“Mok Kah Hong”) at [85]; CSW v CSX [2023] SGHC(A) 23 (“CSW”) at [44] – [46]; TTZ v TTY [2024] SGHCF 46 (“TTZ”) at [17] – [18]; UNE v UNF [2019] SGHCF 96 at [3].

Whether the respondent had breached the court order

10      First, the court determines what the order requires of the respondent, based on the plain meaning of the language used. Any ambiguity is resolved in the respondent’s favour.

11      Second, the court considers whether the respondent has in fact acted in breach of the order (“guilty conduct”).

Whether the respondent had acted with guilty intent

12     If the breach is proved, the court must then determine whether the respondent had acted intentionally – i.e. whether he or she knew that the conduct would contravene the order but nonetheless proceeded with it (“guilty intent”). The respondent’s motive for disobeying the order is irrelevant to liability, although it may bear on his or her sentence.

Burden and standard of proof

13      Finally, the applicant must prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that the respondent committed the guilty conduct with guilty intent. The law imposes this stringent burden of proof because contempt of court carries the potential for imprisonment.

Alleged breach of the Custody Order

14     I will now apply the above principles to the alleged breach of the Custody Order.

Scope of the Custody Order

15     The first step is to determine the proper scope of the Custody Order – specifically, what decisions fall within “custody” rights (and thus require joint decision-making), as opposed to “care and control” rights (which the Mother may exercise alone)?

Custody-related decisions v Care-related decisions

16     To answer this question, a useful starting point is the following guidance in CX v CY (minor: custody and access) [2005] 3 SLR(R) 690 (“CX”):

31    ... where parties are splitting up, custody as a general concept is divided into two smaller packages, ie, “care and control” and residual “custody”. ... [R]esidual “custody” is the package of residual rights that remains after the grant of a care and control order that dictates which parent shall be the daily caregiver of the child and with whom the child shall live. To put it simplistically, “care and control” concerns day-to-day decision-making, while residual “custody” concerns the long-term decision-making for the welfare of the child.

32    As was appropriately summarised by Anthony Dickey in Family Law (LBC Information Services, 3rd Ed, 1997) at pp 326–327:

[A]t common law, care and control concerns the right to take care of a child and to make day-to-day, short-term decisions concerning the child’s upbringing and welfare. Custody without care and control (that is, custody in its narrow sense) concerns the right to make the more important, longer-term decisions concerning the upbringing and welfare of a child.

33    In other words, a “custody order” only gives the parent the residual right to decide on long-term matters affecting the child’s welfare. For instance, the right to decide on the type of education resides with the parent(s) with custody as it concerns the more important and long-term aspects of a child’s upbringing. The right to decide the particular school may also reside with the custodian(s) depending on the importance of this decision to the child’s education. However, the right to decide how a child should dress or travel to school, what sport he should take up or musical instrument he should play and similar ordinary day-to-day matters, resides with the parent who has care and control. Such a demarcation between the two types of orders proposed by Dickey is generally consistent with our local jurisprudence where matters such as choice of schools, tutors or healthcare have been regarded as matters for the custodian(s) to decide (for example, see Yeap Albert v Wong Elizabeth [1998] SGHC 97 at [16]).

34    ...

35    ... We should add that it is an almost impossible task for us to lay down an exhaustive list of matters which will fall under the concept of residual custody. The line is not always clear as to what matters would be considered the important and longer-term decisions concerning the upbringing and welfare of a child. It suffices to say that decisions pertaining to religion, education and major healthcare issues would fall into such a category.

[Bold and underscoring added]

Features of custody-related decisions

17     As evident from CX, the critical distinction between “custody” and “care and control” lies in the nature and extent of the consequences of the decision on the child. Broadly, custody-related decisions are those which have a major impact on a child’s life, whereas care-related decisions are those which has a lesser impact.

18     According to case law, decisions which have a major impact tend to –

(a)      Affect the child’s legal status

Examples include decisions concerning the child’s –

(i)       citizenship: VLI v VLJ [2022] 5 SLR 30 at [15],

(ii)       country of residence: VZJ v VZK [2024] SGHCF 16 (“VZJ”) at [1], [4] and [7],

(iii)       passport application: VZJ at [21], and

(iv)       immigration status: VJM v VJL [2021] 5 SLR 1233 at [3] and [6].

(b)      Shape the child’s identity, beliefs and values

Examples include decisions concerning the child’s –

(i)       surname: UPD v UPC [2020] 4 SLR 699 at [77], and

(ii)       choice of religion: CX at [35].

(c)      Affect the child’s life trajectory

Examples include decisions concerning whether the child –

(i)       Should enrol in a particular school: YG v YH [2008] SGHC 166 (“YG”) at [9],

(ii)       Should enrol in a polytechnic or a junior college: AQL v AQM [2012] 1 SLR 840 at [6], and

(iii)       Should study in Singapore or abroad: VZJ at [1], [4] and [13].

(d)      Carry significant risks for the child

Decisions concerning “major healthcare issues” of the child is a good example: CX at [35]. Logically, such decisions include (i) surgery on the child as well as (ii) starting or stopping the child on treatment for a serious medical condition. In YG, the High Court explained that the wife (as a care-parent) owed the following obligations to the husband who had joint custody of the children:

9    The Wife does not have to consult the Husband on every minor health issue of the children, eg, cold, cough and fever, but is to consult the Husband on every intended hospital admission or hospital procedure unless it is not possible to do so, as in the case of an emergency. If any of the children is hospitalised on an emergency basis, the party having physical care of the child at the time of hospitalisation is to inform the other party as soon as is practicable, for example, within two hours of the start of the emergency.

A similar approach was taken in TAU v TAT [2018] 5 SLR 1089 (“TAU”). There, the court made the following observations:

37    ... I reiterated to the parties that they have joint custody of Emma. It follows from this that they must consult each other and jointly make major healthcare decisions for her. The Mother who has care and control can take care of Emma for minor day-to-day healthcare matters that arise. Nevertheless, in so far as the parties themselves desire to update each other on Emma’s day-to-day healthcare matters, I encouraged the parties’ willingness to co-parent. I understood that the parties made efforts to jointly attend Emma’s regular medical check-ups and physiotherapy appointments.

[Emphasis in bold added]

19     Applying the above principles, the question in the present case is whether the Mother’s decisions to (a) arrange the KKH consultations and (b) change the Daughter’s religious classes are custody-related decisions that required the Father’s consent.

Decision to arrange KKH consultations

20     To assess whether the decision to arrange the KKH consultations is a custody-related decision, it is necessary to examine (a) the reasons for the consultations, (b) what they entailed, and (c) their consequences on the child.

Reasons for the consultations

21     The KKH consultations arose in the following circumstances.[note: 5]

(a)     After the Daughter’s 2019 allegations of sexual touching, she displayed distress and fear towards the Father. From 2020 to 2023, she received counselling from Ms C, a psychologist at a Family Service Centre. The Father knew of this counselling.

(b)     In 2023, the Daughter began speaking about the alleged sexual abuse again. In January 2024, Ms C advised the Mother that it would be best for the Daughter to obtain more structured professional help to deal with her feelings.

What happened at KKH

22     The Mother thus brought the Daughter to KKH in February 2024.[note: 6]

(a)     The child was assessed by KKH’s Psychological Trauma Support Service (“PTSS”) in May 2024. The assessment involved clinical interview, questionnaires, and behavioural observation.

(b)     PTSS found that the Daughter displayed distress reactions as well as fear and avoidance towards the Father. However, they concluded that she did not meet the criteria for post-traumatic stress disorder.

(c)     As at March 2025, the Daughter had attended four PTSS sessions aimed at teaching her coping strategies and helping her manage her emotions.

Do the consultations concern a “major healthcare issue”

23     The Father contends that any decision for the Daughter to see a psychologist is a “major decision” which must be made jointly.[note: 7] This is because the psychological intervention involved an “intrusion” into the child’s mind and could potentially have long-term adverse effects on her.

24     I disagree.

(a)     The Father cites no authority for this sweeping contention.

(b)     Based on his contention, every time that the Mother speaks with the Daughter to understand her feelings and to address her negative emotions would be an “intrusion” into her mind which requires his prior approval. Likewise, every conversation that the child has with a school counsellor – to manage stress or cope with change – would also require his consent. This does not make any sense. A child who is sad needs comfort, a child who is anxious needs reassurance. These are not “major healthcare issues”. Ordinary conversations and emotional support do not become “major healthcare issues” merely because the listener is a psychologist or psychiatrist.

(c)     The Father’s contention is also inconsistent with case law. As shown earlier, courts have emphasised that only decisions concerning “major healthcare issues” engage custodial rights.[note: 8] Such decisions typically involve procedures that are invasive or carry significant risk to a child’s physical or mental integrity. The prescription of psychiatric medication or institutionalisation in a psychiatric facility are some examples.

(d)     In my view, the KKH assessment and counselling do not involve “major healthcare issues”:

(i)       The PTSS assessment consisted of interview, questionnaires, and observation. There is no evidence that the assessment had exposed the Daughter to any risk of physical or mental harm.

(ii)       In its report dated 1 July 2024 (“KKH Report”), KKH assessed that the Daughter did not suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. The Father “respect[ed] and accept[ed]” this assessment.[note: 9] There is no evidence that the child had any major mental condition that would qualify as a “major healthcare issue” requiring his specific attention.

(iii)       Crucially, the Father did not dispute the fact that the KKH consultations (1) were non-invasive and (2) did not have long-term adverse effects on the Daughter. The counselling sessions were intended to simply equip the child with strategies to manage her emotions and were therapeutic in nature. She had found them to be calming and helpful.[note: 10]

(iv)       According to the Father, he had “no emotion” (which I take to mean no strong views) about the Daughter seeing a psychologist.[note: 11] This shows that he does not genuinely view the KKH consultations as raising “major healthcare issues”.

(v)       This is reinforced by the fact that when he had care and control of the Son (June 2022 to November 2024), the Father had taken the child to see counsellors and psychologists without first seeking the Mother’s consent. It is therefore plain that he did not consider the mere act of consulting counsellors or psychologists to be a serious matter which required joint custodial consent.[note: 12]

25     In summary, the Father has failed to show that the Mother’s decision to arrange the KKH consultations had interfered with his joint custody rights. It was a decision that she was entitled to make unilaterally as the Daughter’s care-parent.

Whether the KKH Report was prepared for the purpose of litigation

26     Before moving to the next issue, I wish to address briefly an issue raised by the Father. According to him, the Mother had breached r 35(1) of the Family Justice Rules 2014 (“2014 Rules”) by obtaining the KKH Report and exhibiting it in these proceedings.[note: 13]

27     Rule 35(1) provided that –

Where a child is a party to or a subject of any action or proceedings, or where any action or proceedings involve the welfare or custody of a child, a party must not, without the leave of the Court, cause the child to be examined or assessed by any registered medical practitioner, psychologist, counsellor, social worker or mental health professional for the purpose of preparing expert evidence for use in those proceedings.

[emphasis added]

28     Rule 35(1) has since been superseded by P10, r 4(1) of the Family Justice Rules 2024 (“2024 Rules”). Rule 4(1) provides –

Where any proceedings relate to the welfare or custody of a child, a party must not cause the child to be examined or assessed by any expert for the purpose of preparing expert evidence for use in those proceedings unless the Court approves.

[emphasis added]

29     To bring the Mother’s conduct within r 35(1) and r 4(1), the Father must show that she had caused the Daughter to be examined or assessed for the purpose of preparing expert evidence for use in these committal proceedings.

30     I find that the Mother’s act of procuring the KKH Report did not breach either r 35(1) or r 4(1).

(a)     The Daughter was assessed by PTSS in or around February 2024. In or around June 2024, the Mother requested a report from KKH. The KKH Report was issued in July 2024. The Father commenced the present committal proceedings only in December 2024 – approximately 10 months after the assessment and five months after the report. On this timeline, the Mother could not have arranged the KKH consultations for the purpose of preparing expert evidence in these committal proceedings.

(b)     I also accept the Mother’s evidence that she referred the Daughter to KKH in 2024 because she had wanted healthcare professionals to help the child. The referral was driven by concern for the Daughter’s welfare.[note: 14] KKH’s findings, which confirm that the child had psychological and emotional difficulties at the material time, bear this out.[note: 15] On these facts, the KKH consultations were clearly not for the purpose of litigation.

Decision to change religious classes

31     Next, I turn to the Mother’s decision to change the venue of the Daughter’s religious classes in or around January 2025.

32     The Father contends that this is a breach of the Custody Order and the Mother should thus be held liable for contempt.[note: 16]

33     I have two difficulties with this contention.

No leave was granted

34     The first is procedural.

(a)     It is undisputed that the change of religious classes was not particularised in the Father’s supporting affidavit as a ground for committal. Further, leave was neither sought or granted to pursue it as such.[note: 17] Under P 24, r 7(2) of the 2024 Rules, an applicant “must rely on only the grounds set out in [his or her] supporting affidavit”. Strictly applied, P 24, r 7(2) would require me to disregard the Mother’s decision to change the Daughter’s religious classes as a ground for committal.

(b)     It bears reiterating that (i) the power to punish for contempt is quasi-criminal and (ii) the purpose of P 24, r 7(2) is to safeguard the respondent’s liberty: Mok Kah Hong at [61], [68] – [69]. In the circumstances, P 24, r 7(2) must be scrupulously observed and strictly complied with: Allport Alfred James v Wong Soon Lan [1988] 2 SLR(R) 520 at [8]. Given that no leave had been granted to rely on the Mother’s decision to change the religious classes as a ground for committal, it would be unfair to consider the decision in these proceedings. The Father’s counsel accepted this point in oral submissions.

Pending PPO proceedings

35     The second difficulty is substantive.

(a)     The circumstances leading to the change of religious classes form part of the Mother’s personal protection order (“PPO”) application in SSP 442/xxxx (“SSP 442”). In SSP 442, she alleges that on 5 October 2024, the Father had turned up at the Daughter’s religious class unannounced, asked to see her, and frightened the child (“5 October incident”). She testified that she had changed the venue because she felt that it was no longer safe for the Daughter to continue attending classes at the same location.[note: 18]

(b)     The Mother’s account of the 5 October incident is hotly contested by the Father, both in this committal application and in the PPO proceeding.

(c)     It would be undesirable for this court, in the context of quasi-criminal committal proceedings, to make definitive findings on the same incident which might later be perceived as constraining or pre-empting by the court hearing the PPO proceeding. The safer and fairer approach is to confine my decision in the committal proceeding to matters that properly fall within the leave granted and do not overlap in a way that risks influencing the outcome of SSP 442.

36     Accordingly, I decline to consider the Mother’s change of religious classes as a ground for committal in this proceeding. For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in this judgment should be taken as expressing any view on the 5 October 2024 incident or on whether her decision to change the Daughter’s religious classes is justified.

Alleged breach of Access Order

37     Finally, I turn to the alleged breach of the Access Order.

Applicable principles

Care-parent’s evidential burden

38     A care-parent bears an evidential burden to show that he or she has taken all reasonable efforts to comply with an access order. This burden arises even where it is alleged that the child (i) is unable to see the access-parent or (ii) does not wish to do so: TTZ.

39     In the case of (ii), the care-parent owes a duty to take positive steps and reasonable efforts to enforce the order after learning that the child does not wish to see the access-parent: VRI v VRH [2023] SGHCF 8 (“VRI”) at [16]; TTZ at [19].

40     If there is a complaint of breach, the care-parent must show that he or she has taken genuine and proactive steps that an ordinarily responsible parent could reasonably be expected to take to facilitate access.

Scrutiny of the reasons for the non-access

41     In assessing whether such steps were taken, the court applies an objective test, having regard to all the facts and circumstances: TTZ at [20].

42     In particular, the court will examine whether the asserted reason for non-compliance is true. To give an example – a court may disbelieve a claim that the child could not attend access due to illness if there is evidence that the child was able to travel on public transport at the relevant time or lacked a medical certificate: VRI at [14] and [17].

Claim that the child refused to see the access-parent

43     Where the reason for the non-access is that the child was unwilling to see the access-parent, the court will inquire into the source of the child’s negative feelings and whether they stem from the child or from the care-parent’s influence: WKM v WKN [2024] 1 SLR 158 at [61]; CSW at [63] – [65]. Depending on the circumstances, such an inquiry may take various forms, such as (a) judicial interviews, (b) calling for an access evaluation reports or specific issues report, or (c) assessing relevant evidence adduced by the parties. If the care-parent is found to have influenced the child not to meet the access-parent, this may be viewed as evidence that the care-parent did not intend to comply with the access order: TTZ at [46].

44     Children will, as they mature, develop their own preferences and make their own choices. The assessment into whether the care-parent had made “reasonable efforts” to facilitate access is a practical one: did the parent do what could fairly be expected of him or her, bearing in mind the child’s age, temperament, and the surrounding circumstances? In making this assessment, courts frequently have the challenging task of balancing two considerations.

(a)     As a starting point, parents cannot disclaim all responsibility for their children’s actions. Care-parents remain responsible for guiding their children and setting appropriate limits. An important aspect of this responsibility is facilitating the child’s relationship with the other parent: VDZ v VEA [2020] 4 SLR 921 (“VDZ”) at [45] – [46].

(b)     That said, the child’s welfare – not the wishes or interests of either parent – is paramount. If access is for the child’s welfare, then the child’s willingness (or lack of it) must be factored into the assessment of whether reasonable efforts were made: TTZ at [45].

Where the child genuinely does not wish to meet the access-parent

45     Ultimately, if the care-parent can show that (1) the child genuinely does not wish to see the access-parent, and (2) he or she has taken reasonable efforts to comply with the access order, it is unlikely that the court will force access against the child’s wishes.

(a)     The building of a meaningful parent-child relationship is not amenable to judicial command: WOZ v WOY [2024] SGHCF 11 at [4]. The law cannot compel a child to love a parent: TEN v TEO [2020] SGHCF 20 at [43].

(b)     Forcing access in the above circumstances will not assist in repairing the parent-child relationship. It may in fact strain the relationship further, and even traumatise the child: VDZ at [27].

(c)     Parties should consider other ways of communicating and parenting to pave the way for meaningful access in future: TTZ at [23] and [53].

46     One further point. Given that the applicant/access-parent bears the burden of proof beyond reasonable doubt, it follows that the respondent/care-parent will not be liable for contempt if he or she –

(a)     can prove [45(1)] and [45(2)] on a balance of probabilities, or

(b)     can raise a reasonable doubt that the breach was intentional – even if he or she is unable to prove [45(1)] and [45(2)] on a balance of probabilities.

Summing-up

47     In summary, once a breach of an access order is shown, the care-parent must establish that he or she took reasonable efforts to comply. This, in turn, requires establishing three matters. One, the reason for the child’s alleged inability or unwillingness to meet the access-parent. Two, whether the care-parent had caused or contributed to that situation (including whether the care-parent had influenced the child not to see the access-parent). Three, the steps taken by the care-parent to enforce the order.

My decision

48     I now apply these principles to the present case.

Mother’s explanation for non-access

49     According to the Mother, she could not facilitate the access during the Relevant Access Period because the Daughter was “terrified” at the mere mention of meeting the Father and “resolutely refused” to see him.[note: 19]

Daughter corroborated the Mother’s explanation

50     The Daughter corroborated the Mother’s account. She testified that she knew of the Access Order and understood that she was to see the Father. However, she was “scared” of him – even during supervised access. She did not want to meet him.[note: 20]

51     The Daughter explained that this fear stemmed from the following.[note: 21]

(a)      Sexual touching in 2019

She testified that the Father had touched her sexually on two occasions and she was afraid that he would do so again.

(b)      Touching in 2022

She described multiple instances where he draped his arm around her shoulder, hugged her from behind, and pulled her closer without her permission during access periods in public places. She found the experience uncomfortable.

(c)      Attempt to drive away with the Daughter in 2022

She recounted an incident during supervised access where he carried her up and tried to take her away in his car, causing a commotion that required the intervention of mall security.

(d)      Non-return of the Son in 2022

She understood that the Father had taken the Son for the June holidays and did not return him to the Mother’s care thereafter. She feared that he would do the same to her.

52     If believed, the Daughter’s evidence would prove that the Mother did not deliberately disobey the Access Order – and that the child was the one who had prevented the access from occurring. The critical question is whether I should accept the child’s evidence.

The “unusually convincing” standard

53     The Father submits that the Daughter’s evidence should be rejected because it is “not unusually convincing”, citing Public Prosecutor v GHI [2023] SGDC 295 at [17].[note: 22] The Mother argues that the “unusually convincing” standard does not apply because these are not criminal proceedings.[note: 23]

54     At the outset, I note that the phrase “unusually convincing” does not establish a different standard of proof. It is a cautionary reminder in criminal cases that where the Prosecution’s case rests largely or solely on the uncorroborated evidence of a single witness. In such cases, the court must examine that evidence with special care before being satisfied that guilt has been proved beyond reasonable doubt: Public Prosecutor v GCK [2020] 1 SLR 486 (“GCK”) at [87], [91], [98], [99], [104], [137], [144], [145], [149].

55     The courts have not yet addressed whether the “unusually convincing” standard applies in committal proceedings.

56     In this case, it is unnecessary to decide that question. This is because even if I were to assume that the standard applies in contempt cases, it does not assist the Father for three reasons.

(a)      First, in criminal cases, the “unusually convincing” standard is directed at the Prosecution’s evidence – not the accused person’s or defendant’s. The standard is used to assess whether the Prosecution’s sole witness is so reliable, credible and plausible that his or her uncorroborated testimony can be the basis for conviction. The Daughter, however, is a witness called in support of the Mother’s defence – not the Father’s case.

(b)      Second, it is wrong in principle to require an accused person (in criminal cases) or a respondent (in committal) to satisfy the “unusually convincing” threshold in order to raise a reasonable doubt. This unreasonably reverses the burden and standard of proof in criminal and committal proceedings.

(c)      Third, and in any event, the Daughter’s account of her fears and of the key incidents underpinning those fears is materially corroborated by independent or undisputed evidence. As such, there is no need to trigger the cautionary reminder.

(i)        Sexual touching in 2019

In relation to the sexual touching incidents, (1) police reports were lodged, (2) the Daughter was referred for medical examination, (3) Child Protection Services was activated, and (4) the child was followed up by social service agencies for several years thereafter. In highlighting these undisputed facts, I make no finding regarding whether the sexual touching incidents did in fact occur. I remain conscious of the fact that these incidents have been strongly disputed, are not the subject of this committal application, and the parties did not lead full evidence regarding them. I refer to the foregoing matters only to note that the Daughter’s account of the incidents is not a recent fabrication.

(ii)        Touching in 2022

It is undisputed that the Father had physical contact with the Daughter during access at public places. Given her claims regarding the sexual touching incidents in 2019, it is unsurprising that she felt uncomfortable to such contact from him.

(iii)        Attempt to drive away with the Daughter in 2022

A video of the incident shows that despite the Daughter wanting to remain with the Mother, the Father had (1) carried the child away from the Mother, (2) forced her into his car, and (3) intended to drive off with the child. The video also shows the Daughter to be crying.[note: 24] According to the Father, he had merely wanted to bring her to a mosque and did not harbour any ulterior motive. In my view, even if he had acted with innocent intent, the fact is that the child was clearly distressed by his actions.

(iv)        Non-return of the Son in 2022

It is undisputed that the Father had breached the 2020 Order by refusing to return the Son to the Mother after the June 2022 holidays.[note: 25] The Daughter’s concern that he might do likewise to her is not inherently incredible.

Taken together, the above events, and the fact that the Daughter has been in counselling for several years since 2019, demonstrate that there is a factual foundation for her fear of the Father.

Did the Mother coach the Daughter

57     The Father submits that the Mother had coached the Daughter to testify that she did not wish to see him and caused the child to be fearful of him. He highlights that the Daughter repeatedly expressed a fear of being taken away even though, apart from the 2022 incident, he had not actually done so.[note: 26]

58     I am not persuaded by the Father’s submission.

(a)      First, the mere fact that the Father did not attempt to forcibly take her away after the 2022 incident does not render the Daughter’s fear of him to be illogical. As explained above, there is a confluence of factors contributing to such a fear.

(b)      Second, even if the fear were irrational, that would not, by itself, prove that the Daughter had been coached or that the Mother caused or contributed to the child’s fear.

(c)      Third, there is nothing in the evidence to suggest that the Mother had coached the Daughter.

(i)       The child is emotionally mature and intellectually precocious. For instance, she expressed frustration that despite repeatedly telling many people about the “incidents”, the matter had not been resolved, and she did not feel believed.[note: 27] She testified that she wished for all of this to stop so she could stay with the Mother.[note: 28]

(ii)       She spoke plainly and candidly acknowledged when she could not recall or was unsure of details.

(iii)       Her tone was measured – there was no hint of animosity or bias towards the Father.

59     I therefore find that the Daughter’s evidence about her fear of the Father is credible, supported by objective/undisputed evidence, and is not the product of coaching.

Did the Mother influence the Daughter not to meet the Father

60     I next consider whether the Mother had caused or contributed to the Daughter’s unwillingness to meet the Father during the Relevant Access Period.

61     In my view, she did not.

(a)      First, the Daughter testified that the Mother did not say anything bad about the Father to her.

(b)      Second, the Mother appears to have shielded the Daughter from her own views about the Father. The Daughter testified that the Mother did not tell her what transpired at court hearings with the Father.[note: 29] When she asked why the Son did not return after the June holidays, the Mother replied that she did not know[note: 30] – even though it is undisputed that the Father had unlawfully retained the Son.

(c)      Third, the Father did not provide any concrete evidence to show (i) that the Mother had influenced the Daughter not to meet him during the Relevant Access Period, (ii) why the child’s evidence should be disbelieved, and (iii) why the Mother would want to intentionally frustrate his access with the child.[note: 31]

Did the Mother take reasonable efforts to enforce the Access Order

62     I now turn to the final issue: whether the Mother had taken reasonable efforts to enforce the Access Order during the Relevant Access Period.

63     On the facts, the Mother did make efforts to comply with the order.

(a)     The Daughter testified that the Mother had informed her of upcoming access sessions several days in advance.

(b)     The Mother did not merely adopt a passive stance when it came to facilitating access. Even before the Access Order was made in November 2024, she had taken active steps to restore the Father – Daughter relationship.

(i)       She arranged the KKH consultations to address the Daughter’s fear of the Father. The Daughter testified that she had benefited from these consultations.

(ii)       She had also approached the Community Psychology Hub (“CPH”) regarding access difficulties. On 27 September 2024, CPH proposed various interventions, including (1) their involvement in facilitating sessions between the Father and Daughter, (2) participation in the “Children of Divorce Intervention Programme”, and (3) co-parenting work with CPH and REACH to improve the parent–child relationship and co-parenting dynamics. [note: 32]

64     The Father however contends that the Mother had not done enough. He relies on the following aspects of the Daughter’s evidence to support his contention.[note: 33]

(a)     When the Daughter testified that she did not want to meet him, the Mother had told her she was sorry she “had to go” for access, but that she could choose not to go.

(b)     The Mother did not persuade the child to attend, nor did she tell her that she (the Mother) might get into trouble if access did not take place. Instead, the Mother said that she would “sort out” the matter.

65     I agree that in a typical case, it would not suffice for a care-parent simply to say: “The child refuses to go for access, and I cannot force him or her to act otherwise.” Such passivity does not meet the requirement of reasonable effort. Nor is it acceptable if a parent, consciously or otherwise, communicates negative views about the access-parent or fails to create an emotionally conducive environment for access. The care-parent is expected to take positive steps to promote the child’s relationship with the access-parent – access is a right of the child, not merely a privilege for the access-parent.

66     However, this is not a typical case.

(a)      First, it appears that the Daughter’s fear of the Father is deep-seated, long-standing, and anchored in undisputed events as well as serious (though un-established) allegations of sexual misconduct. I must factor all these into the assessment of whether requiring the Mother to do significantly more to get the child to attend access would risk trauma or harm, bearing in mind that the duty to comply with an access order must yield to the paramount consideration of the child’s welfare: s 125 of the Women’s Charter (“Charter”).

(b)      Second, the Mother’s decision to tell the Daughter that she had a choice whether to meet the Father, and not to press the child further, must also be considered in light of the Father’s unreasonable stance.

(i)       On 30 September 2024, the Father responded to CPH’s proposals by citing extracts from Family Court judgments and writing cryptically: “There is no assurance that [the Daughter] would (ever) be deemed ‘ready’ for proposed joint parent–child sessions, isn’t it”. He then expressly declined the proposed intervention plans.[note: 34]

(ii)       During cross-examination, the Father insisted that even if the Daughter told him in person that she was fearful and did not wish to see him, this would not satisfy him.[note: 35] Additionally, he disagreed that the appropriate response would be to help her address such fears if the child was unwilling to see him.[note: 36]

The above stance of the Father shows that he does not regard the Daughter’s feelings as being relevant. In my view, his mindset carries a real risk that he will disregard what the child says to him during unsupervised access and thereby heighten her fear.

67     Given the above, the Mother was placed in a difficult position. The Daughter was genuinely terrified. Professional counsellors proposed gradual reintroduction. The Father rejected that approach and insisted on immediate, unsupervised access based on the Access Order.

68     In my view, it would not be reasonable to expect the Mother to disregard the Daughter’s emotional state, compel access at all costs, and risk re-traumatising the child. I am satisfied that the Mother had taken reasonable and good-faith steps to facilitate access. She did not act in defiance of the Access Order – she had reacted to the child’s genuine fear and distress. The steps that she had taken – seeking professional assistance and exploring therapeutic solutions – show compliance with both the letter and the spirit of the Access Order.

69     Accordingly, I find that the Father has failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the Mother had wilfully disobeyed the Access Order.

70     At this juncture, I wish to emphasise a few points.

(a)      First, this decision should not be read as a general licence for care-parents to treat access as being optional. It is confined to the exceptional facts of this case: (i) the Daughter’s fear has a documented history and is corroborated by multiple sources, (ii) the Mother had sought professional help for the Daughter’s fear and had proposed a graduated approach to reintroducing the Father into the child’s life, and (iii) the Father had unreasonably rejected those efforts and insisted on immediate compliance on the Access Order. In these circumstances, the Mother’s conduct was protective (rather than defiant) and was directed at the Daughter’s welfare (rather than the exclusion of the Father). To characterise her actions as contemptuous is incompatible with both the welfare principle and the therapeutic aims of family justice.

(b)      Second, the law does not allow a care-parent to avoid compliance merely by saying that the child has “chosen” not to attend. A care-parent may be liable for contempt if he or she passively abdicates responsibility, deliberately obstructs access under the guise of the child’s reluctance, and/or fails to take genuine steps to encourage and facilitate access – for example, by disparaging the access-parent or affirming the child’s refusal to meet the access-parent.

(c)      Third, my finding that the Mother was not in contempt during the Relevant Access Period does not vary, rescind, or suspend the Access Order. It remains in full force. My finding simply reflects the finding that, during the Relevant Access Period, physical access could not occur because of the unique circumstances that I had described.

(d)      Finally, if either party considers that the existing access arrangements should be substantively changed, the proper course is to seek a variation in accordance with the legal requirements. Until it is varied, the Access Order remains the baseline against which the parties’ future conduct – whether in facilitating or seeking to enforce access – will be evaluated.

Conclusion

71     For the above reasons, the Father’s committal application is dismissed.

72     Before I conclude, a few words for the parties.

To the Mother

(a)     It is good practice to keep your ex-spouse informed of developments in your daughter’s life – even if you are not legally obliged to do so. A lack of information can breed suspicion. If he comes to discover these developments, he may wonder – “Am I being cut out of my child’s life? What else am I not being told?”

(b)     I appreciate that providing information may lead to further acrimony between the two of you – and worse, attempts to frustrate your efforts to care and help your daughter. You are likely to be worried that he may react unreasonably or seek to obstruct. I have no easy answer to address your dilemma save to say this – if you can demonstrate that you are acting transparently and in good faith, the law will have no difficulty deciding who is the more responsible parent and in supporting your decisions as the care-parent.

(c)     Finally, I recognise your dissatisfaction with aspects of the 2024 Order and your emotional difficulty of complying with them. Nonetheless, I must reiterate that until those orders are rescinded or varied, they must be obeyed.

To the Father

(d)     The Access Order is not a certificate of entitlement to be enforced in disregard of your daughter’s emotional state. The law cannot compel a child to love a parent. It is difficult to see how imprisoning your daughter’s primary care-giver will be in her best interests.[note: 37] It will not make her less afraid. It will certainly make matters worse.

(e)     If you genuinely wish to restore your relationship with your daughter, you will need to listen to her more, acknowledge her fear towards you (even if you believe it to be unjustified), and accept professional guidance on how to move forward. The path will not be easy – especially as your daughter is now entering the teenage years. Winning your daughter’s affections back will require persuasion, patience, and perseverance.

(f)     Finally, the law strives for balance – orders must be obeyed, but always with the child’s welfare as the guiding light. Your attempts at reconciling with your daughter are more likely to be successful if you heed these words to guide your future actions.

html:
XUP v XUQ and another matter

XUP v XUQ and another matter
[2025] SGFC 125

Case Number:FC/OSM 184 & 286 of 2023, HCF/DCA 80 & 81 of 2025
Decision Date:14 November 2025
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Jason Gabriel Chiang
Counsel Name(s): Mr Bernard Chiu (Lexcompass LLC) for P's Ex-Wife; Mr James Chai (instructed counsel) for P's Ex-Wife; Mr Simon Tan and Mr Nikolas Wong (Attorneys Inc LLC) for P's Sister
Parties: XUP — XUQ — XUR — XUS — XUT

Mental Capacity Act 2008 – Mental Capacity – Best Interest of P – Deputies – Appointment of Deputies – Selection of persons for appointment as Deputies

14 November 2025

District Judge Jason Gabriel Chiang:

Introduction

1       Deputies take on the onerous duties and responsibilities of making decisions on behalf of a person who lacks mental capacity (“P”) in relation to P’s personal welfare and/or property and affairs in the furtherance of P’s best interests. Where there is a contest between parties as to who should be appointed as the deputy/deputies of P, the Court will have to decide on which person or persons, whether they be P’s family members or other persons close to P, to be appointed as the deputy/deputies of P as well as the scope of their powers.

2       The saying “blood is thicker than water” is often misused. The plain reading of this saying suggests that the familial bonds are stronger than other relationships. In this regard, an argument was made during the proceedings that the Court should favour the appointment of a family member to be P’s deputy. However, there is recognised scholarly discourse that the original saying was actually used in the military context of describing that the “water of the womb” is not thicker than the “blood of the covenant”, suggesting that one's blood covenant in battle or through adversity could be more important than a person’s familial bonds.

3       While paragraph 50 of the Family Justice Courts Practice Directions 2015 (which is substantially the same as paragraph 74 of the Family Justice Courts Practice Directions 2024) does suggest that P’s immediate family members, by virtue of their relationship to P, are likely to have an interest, such that they should be notified as Relevant Persons of any proceedings under the Mental Capacity Act 2008 (“MCA”) relating to P, this presumption is rebuttable. Persons who are not immediate family members could very well be closer to P or concerned over the care and financial management of P for them to be considered as Relevant Persons. Whereas family members who are estranged or wholly uninvolved or unconcerned about P’s care may not be Relevant Persons.

4       Similarly, the person that the Court appoints as P’s deputy, who must be a Relevant Person, may be a family member, but there could potentially be a person outside of the immediate family that would better placed to be appointed as P’s deputy to serve P’s best interests. The Court, thus, has to consider the specific circumstances and relationships that the proposed deputies have with P to select the right person or persons to be P’s deputy/deputies.

5       The applications of FC/OSM 184/2023 (“OSM 184”) and FC/OSM 286/2023 (“OSM 286”) presented competing applications for the appointment of a deputy for P. OSM 184 was commenced by the ex-wife of P (the “Ex-Wife”), who had been coparenting P an P’s Ex-Wife’s 2 sons aged 15 and 13 with P (the “Sons”) in a largely cordial manner prior to P’s stroke. OSM 286 was commenced by the elder sister of P (the “Sister”), whom P also had a fairly good relationship with. P’s Ex-Wife and P’s Sister disagreed on the care of P and how P’s property and assets should be managed. The Court had the unenviable task of deciding whom to appoint as the deputy for P or whether both P’s Ex-Wife and P’s Sister could work collaboratively as P’s deputies and the range of powers for said deputyship that would be in P’s best interest. Ultimately, after considering the evidence and parties’ arguments, P’s Ex-Wife was unable to convince the Court that she instead of P’s Sister was better placed to be P’s deputy. Instead, P’s Sister evidenced consistent care of P. Hence, P’s Sister was appointed as the sole deputy for P with certain specified powers. Therefore, OSM 184 was dismissed, and orders were made in OSM 286. P’s Ex-Wife being dissatisfied with my decision, filed appeals against both of the decisions in OSM 184 with HCF/DCA 80/2025 and in OSM 286 with HCF/DCA 81/2025.

Facts

The parties

6       P was a Singaporean businessman who had suffered a stroke in March 2023 at the age of 48. As of the time of the decision, P was about 50 years old and was under the care of a nursing home.

7       P’s Sister, also a Singaporean, was five (5) years older than him and was his only sibling. P’s and P’s Sister’s parents had passed away quite some time prior to these proceedings.

8       P’s Ex-Wife was a Singaporean woman who was about 42 years old at the time of the decision. P’s Ex-Wife worked as a math tuition teacher, either working out of her residence or over zoom.

Background to the dispute

P’s relationships with P’s Ex-Wife’s and P’s Sister and their relationship with each other

9       P and P’s Ex-Wife were married in July 2008. P’s and P’s Ex-Wife’s 1st Son was born in January 2010 and then 2nd Son was born in January 2012.

10     On 5 January 2018, P filed for divorce against the Ex-Wife on the grounds of irretrievable breakdown of the marriage based on the factual scenario that the Ex-Wife had behaved in a manner that it would be unreasonable for him to stay in the marriage. In the divorce proceedings, P had alleged that there were many disagreements and quarrels between P’s Ex-Wife and him, and that P’s Ex-Wife would keep late nights away from P and the family. P found P’s Ex-Wife to be stubborn and would have outbursts of anger and that there was a lack of communication and understanding for his financial situation which added to his stress. Due to this, they ceased conjugal relationships since 2011 (i.e. shortly after the conception of the 2nd Son) and had slept separately since. While the Ex-Wife filed a memorandum of appearance, she indicated she was not contesting and did not file a defence to these claims.

11     The Interim Judgment was pronounced on 5 April 2018 with a consent order for all ancillary matters. Pursuant to this, P and P’s Ex-Wife shared joint custody with care and control going to P’s Ex-Wife and P granted liberal access to P’s Sons. P was also to make monthly maintenance payments of S$1,600 payable to P’s Ex-Wife being half of the purported expenses for both of P’s Sons to be paid at the start of each month. The Final Judgment for divorce was then granted on 9 July 2018.

12     P had made certain comments to friends and on social media which appeared to suggest that he believed P’s Ex-Wife had an extramarital affair with a parent of one of her tuition students. During the course of proceedings, it was belatedly revealed that P’s Ex-Wife had a third child, a son, who was not P’s biological offspring and was aged 6 years old (the “Little Boy”). Based on the fact that he was born in the 1st quarter of 2019, the Little Boy would have been conceived either during P’s and P’s Ex-Wife’s marriage or shortly after the Interim Judgment had been pronounced. As at the time of the hearings, P’s Ex-Wife appeared not to be in any romantic relationship with another person. P’s Ex-Wife claimed that the Little Boy would be care for by her mother on most days at her mother’s residence instead of at her residence.

P’s Ex-Wife claims that P remained her close friend and confidant despite their divorce.

Given the status of their fairly close relationship, P had also facilitated P’s Sister’s contact with P’s 2 Sons, where messages were provided evidencing that the P’s 2 Sons would independently seek to speak with P’s Sister and provide her with updates. P’s Sister’s son was also allowed by P to utilize the facilities at P’s residence. P and P’s Sister would also have regular meetups for family events. While P had more frequent contact with P’s Ex-Wife, these do seem to be centred around P’s 2 Sons, whereas P’s contact with P’s Sister while less frequent, was consistent and friendly.

16     According to P’s Sister, just prior to his stroke, P had voluntarily intimated to her that he was dating another woman and was in a “long term relationship” since sometime in 2022. P’s Ex-Wife was unaware of any such person. However, since P’s stroke, no such person has come forward and parties could not locate any such person.

17     Other than P’s 2 Sons, P’s Sister would be P’s closest family member. By all accounts, it appeared that P was fairly involved in the lives of P’s Sons. P’s stroke and subsequent hospitalization.

20     On 23 March 2023, P suffered sudden onset of right-sided weakness (i.e. hemiplegia) and difficulty talking. He was admitted to National University Hospital (“NUH”) where he was diagnosed with a left-sided haemorrhagic stroke. An emergency craniectomy was conducted. A 2nd surgery was also conducted on 26 March 2023 to relieve pressure in his brain. When his condition improved, he was transferred to Alexandra Hospital (“AH”) on 14 April 2023 for rehabilitation. P was initially making incremental improvements post-stroke on this basis.

21     However, P had to be readmitted to NUH for an infection and swelling in June 2023, where he suffered two (2) seizures and pneumonia. He was then diagnosed with ischemic stroke. He was subsequently transferred to AH for a rehabilitative program in July 2023, and then to Crawfurd Hospital before being transferred to All Saints Home (Jurong East) (“ASH”) on 9 October 2023, where he remains. P’s accommodation at ASH was a non-airconditioned ward that was shared with seven (7) other residents. P’s Ex-Wife had provided a portable evaporative air cooler to make his stay more comfortable.

22     When P first suffered his stroke on 23 March 2023, P’s Ex-Wife was initially appointed by NUH to be P’s spokesperson. However, sometime around 25 March 2023, P’s Ex-Wife voluntarily relinquished this role and P’s Sister was appointed as P’s spokesperson. After 31 March 2023, P’s Ex-Wife was purportedly not allowed to visit P for a period of time. P’s Ex-Wife subsequently resumed visits with P at ASH.

Parties contact with P

According to P’s Sister, there was nothing to suggest at that point in time that P’s Ex-Wife and P had reconciled for P’s Ex-Wife to be provided such access. P’s Sister alleged that it was P’s Ex-Wife who initiated hostility and tried to alienate his family members from visiting him. P’s Sister insisted that she consistently ensured that P’s Ex-Wife and P’s 2 Sons were kept informed of P’s medical condition and that P’s Ex-Wife blocked all correspondence from her instead.

25     P’s Ex-Wife claimed that she and P’s 2 Sons would visit regularly while P was at NUH, AH and ASH.
